slidetitle.en_BE: Subsidies to new EU members in millions of euros
slidetitle.fr_FR: Subventions aux nouveaux états-membres de l'UE en millions d'euros

slidetext.en_BE:
After the successive enlargements of the European Union, agricultural subsidies to farmers of post-socialist countries increased a lot.

More than €10 billion flow to them annually. (All data in this report comes from Eurostat, the European statistical agency).
slidetext.fr_FR: Après l'élargissement de l'Union Européenne aux pays d'Europe post-socialiste en 2004, 2007 et 2013, les subventions aux agriculteurs de ces pays ont augmenté.

slidetitle.en_BE: Indirect subsidies to new EU members in millions of euros
slidetitle.fr_FR: Subventions indirectes aux nouveaux états-membres de l'UE en millions d'euros

slidetext.en_BE:
Some subsidies are indirect subsidies. They can be tied to the crops farmers grow.

Subsidies on products were reduced because they fell foul of the rules of the World Trade Organization. Indeed, some of this money was used to dump European crops on world markets, thereby depressing prices worldwide.
slidetext.fr_FR: Certaines subventions sont des subventions indirectes. Elles sont liées aux types de cultures plantées, par exemple.

slidetitle.en_BE: Direct subsidies to new EU members in millions of euros
slidetitle.fr_FR: Subventions directes aux nouveaux états-membres de l'UE en millions d'euros

slidetext.en_BE:
Most of the subsidies are now direct subsidies. It’s a lump sum of money given per hectare. The larger the fields, the more money farmers receive.

The "Single Payment Scheme", which replaced indirect subsidies, was enacted in the 2003 reform of the CAP. Another reform, in 2013, the name changed to "Basic Payment Scheme" but the rationale remain: larger payments to larger farms.
slidetext.fr_FR: La majeure partie des subventions sont des subventions directes, données par hectare. Plus la surface cultivée est grande, plus les agriculteurs touchent de subventions.

slidetitle.en_BE: Subsidies to Bulgarian farmers in millions of euros
slidetitle.fr_FR: Subventions aux fermes bulgares en millions d'euros

slidetext.en_BE:
The proportion of direct subsidies is even higher in Bulgaria.

In member-states that joined the EU after 2004, the share of direct subsidies is 78%. It is 85% in Bulgaria.
slidetext.fr_FR: La proportion de subventions directe est encore plus élevée en Bulgarie.

slidetitle.en_BE: Average farm size in Bulgaria in hectares
slidetitle.fr_FR: Taille moyenne des exploitations bulgares en hectares

slidetext.en_BE:
Direct subsidies incentivize farmers to produce a lot, over large areas. Indeed, Bulgarian farms became bigger. The graph shows that the average farm size increase fourfold, from 5 hectares in 2003 to almost 20 today.

While small farmers can apply for some subsidies and are, in theory, encouraged to do so, the complexity of the paperwork is such that, in effect, they have little chance of receiving as much money as big landholders.
slidetext.fr_FR: Les subventions directes poussent les agriculteurs à produire sur des surfaces plus grandes. Les exploitations bulgares sont devenues plus grandes.

slidetitle.en_BE: Production of Bulgarian farms in millions of euros
slidetitle.fr_FR: Production des exploitations bulgares en millions d'euros

slidetext.en_BE:
Production in Bulgaria increased, too. Over the last 15 years, it went from €3 billion to €4 billion per year.

The increase in production is almost exactly equal to the increase in subsidies. One euro of subsidy led to an increase of one euro in product. In other words, the net effect of subsidies was nil.

slidetitle.en_BE: Production of Bulgarian farms in millions of euros
slidetitle.fr_FR: Production des exploitations bulgares en millions d'euros

slidetext.en_BE:
Production increased mostly in crops that require large fields, such as corn, wheat or sunflower. They are presented as "cash crops" on the graph.

Demand for such crops increased due to a boom in biofuels, meat production and exports to "land-grabbing" companies from the Arabian Peninsula, among others. The Basic Payment Scheme incentivizes farmers to follow such trends.
slidetext.fr_FR:
La production a principalement augmentée pour les cultures qui nécessitent des grands champs, comme le mais, le blé ou le tournesol.

Ce sont ce qu'on appelle des cultures industrielles.

slidetitle.en_BE: Production of Bulgarian farms in millions of euros
slidetitle.fr_FR: Production des exploitations bulgares en millions d'euros

slidetext.en_BE: Growth in cash crops occured at the expense of other produce. For vegetables, a traditional cultivation tradition in Bulgaria, production in value actually decreased by a factor of four!
slidetext.fr_FR: Pour les légumes, une culture traditionnelle en Bulgarie, la production a même diminué!

slidetitle.en_BE: Production of vegetables in Bulgaria in volume (2001 = 100)
slidetitle.fr_FR: Production de légumes en Bulgarie en volume (2001 = 100)

slidetext.en_BE: The decrease in the production of vegetables shows across the board, from tomatoes to carrots to cabbage. The decrease occured both in tonnage (visualized here) and in value (visualized on the previous graph).
slidetext.fr_FR: La baisse de la production de légume se voit pour tout, des tomates aux choux, en passant par les carottes.

data.label: Germany (until 1990 former territory of the FRG)

slidetext.en_BE: Bulgaria and some others clearly gave up on growing vegetables. In some countries, the production of vegetables in value increased, as is shown here. However, production in volume (tonnage), decreased in almost every country.
slidetext.fr_FR: La Bulgarie et quelques autres ont clairement abandonné les légumes, mais ce n'est pas le cas partout.

data.label: Germany (until 1990 former territory of the FRG)

slidetitle.en_BE: Production of cash crops in value (2000 = 100)
slidetitle.fr_FR: Production de cultures industrielles en valeur (2000 = 100)

slidetext.en_BE: Even where the production of vegetables increased, its growth pales in comparison to cash crops, especially in countries that joined the EU after 2004. Almost everywhere, production of wheat, sunflower or soya grew more than production of vegetables and fruits.
slidetext.fr_FR: Mais comparée aux cultures industrielle, la croissance de la production de légumes fait pale figure, surtout dans les pays qui ont rejoint l'UE en 2004 et 2007.

slidetitle.en_BE: Salaried employment in agriculture in the EU in  thousands of full-time equivalent
slidetitle.fr_FR: Emploi salarié dans l'agriculture dans l'UE en milliers d'équivalents temps pleins

slidetext.en_BE: Despite the large increase in production, salaried employment in agriculture in Europe remained flat. Two and a half million Europeans work as full-time farmers, exactly as many as 15 years ago.
slidetext.fr_FR: Malgré l'augmentation de la production, l'emploi salarié dans l'agriculture a stagné.

slidetitle.en_BE: Non-salaried employment in agriculture in the EU in  thousands of full-time equivalent
slidetitle.fr_FR: Emploi non-salarié dans l'agriculture dans l'UE en milliers d'équivalents temps pleins

slidetext.en_BE:
More importantly, employment of seasonal workers has dropped dramatically. Over 12 million full-time equalivalents were employed as seasonal workers in 2000. The figure is less than half today. (The data represent full-time equalivalents. Because it requires several seasonal workers to match a full-time equalivalent, the number of actual people impacted is much higher.)

Cash crops are profitable because they cover a lot of land (which brings in direct subsidies) and require very few seasonal workers. As a result, unemployment grows.
slidetext.fr_FR:
Plus important, l'emploi de travailleurs saisonniers a largement baissé.

Les cultures industrielles sont profitables parce qu'elles couvrent une large surface (qui rapporte des subventions) et nécessitent peu de travailleurs.

data.label: Germany (until 1990 former territory of the FRG)

slidetitle.en_BE: Non-salaried employment in agriculture by country (2000 = 100)
slidetitle.fr_FR: Emploi non-salarié dans l'agriculture dans l'UE (2000 = 100)

slidetext.en_BE: Unsurprisingly, countries where the production of cash crops increased most saw the steepest decline in seasonal employment. In Bulgaria, out of 4 seasonal workers who would have found employment in 2000, just one could still do so today.
slidetext.fr_FR: Sans surprise, les pays où les cultures industrielles ont le plus progressé sont ceux où l'emploi saisonnier a le plus diminué.
